lets say i am a bit new on the workings of junit..so how is it that 
one can test a private method...just to make sure it does what it is 
supposed to do.

Regards,

Chucks Ezeugoh
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> 
wrote:
> Mark Xu wrote:
> 
> > should it be the same as the packge for the source
> > codes been tested or not?
> > 
> > my colleagues argued that it makes it easy to test
> > the protected methods or packge scope methods if
> > they live in the same package.
> 
> Yes, it does. Question: why test protected methods? Further 
question: 
> why make the method protected in the first place?
> 
> Testing non-public parts of an interface creates unnecessary 
coupling 
> between tests and production code, hindering refactoring. If you 
care 
> about having the freedom to refactor, then don't test non-public 
> methods. If you want to test a non-public method, then maybe it 
> shouldn't be public.
> 
> Search the archives of this group for more detailed arguments.
> 
> Take care.
> -- 
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
> Let's write software that people understand
